reviewText: Once I got past the ad for Denise's zillion and one tapes, and became accustomed to her slightly saccharine voice, I had nothing but admiration for this woman who has tremendous knowledge in how a body works, and knows how to articulate it.This is the best exercise video I've ever tried. The others have been confusing, boring, hard to follow, or don't live up to their promises. This one has none of these bad traits, and the the key to these workouts is balance: The sequence of the movements provides your body with enough change so that a particular muscle or area won't receive undue stress.It's divided into 2 twenty minute workouts, that are simple yet for me personally, enough of a challenge to keep me interested for months to come, and will be a perfect substitute for my walking routine when the weather won't coöperate.The first one, the Pilates style mat exercises, gave me from the start, a better posture, and a feeling of inner strength. Standing taller and feeling more relaxed in the shoulder/neck area than before.The second one is my favorite. A yoga based combination that is superbly blended for flexibility and strength...and yes, I love that she wobbles more on some poses than I do...it makes this "woman of steel" human, and you've got to love her for this video, and what it will do for your body.Tolstoy said: "The only misfortunes in life are remorse and illness". This video will help keep you healthy, and you won't regret buying it.
summary: do your body a favor...buy this video !
Title: N/A

reviewText: Speaking for myself, I don't know any Yoga.  So, when I tried this DVD, I was extremely disappointed!  I've had this DVD for 9+ years and I STILL DO NOT LIKE IT.No instructions - or not enough of them - I don't know which it is.  But, this Pilates DVD is not good.  They assume that you already know what you are doing, even if you don't.It is also very hard to understand Denise Austin - her raspy voice at times impossible to understand.If you are a beginner or just simply looking for a good Pilates workout - Do Not buy this one.I DO RECOMEND: *** "Mari Windsor" ***, she knows what she is doing and takes the time to go into detail as to how to do the workouts.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this DVD a while ago, but I've been recently doing a lot of Yourself Fitness which does a lot of cardio, and I needed to strengthen my core.First 22 minute session goes like this:*Warm up = Arm Stretches - up/down/twisting both sides and lean over on both sides, legs swaying, etc.*Bridge*Hundreds - ie, arms going up and down, torso raised, breathing in 5 in and 5 out, then legs raised, still doing Hundreds.*Leg Circles in the air - on your back making circles with each leg outstretched.  Small then large circles.  Alternating legs.*Roll Like A Ball - 4x, rolling back and forth with feet not touching*Single Leg Stretch aka Bicycles - torso up, knees to chest, parallel to the floor alternating*V ups - (or something similar), legs raised arms out, torso raised, bring knees to chest and release, several times*Scissors - torso up, breathing in 2, out 2, legs up and down alternating with your arms holding your legs, torso up*Criss Cross - legs back in bicycles formation, torso up, and alternate your torso going from knee to knee, same as bicycles only your arms are behind your head and you're alternating knees and torso elbow*Modified Teaser & then Teaser - Both legs up in a V, with your torso and arms in alignment.  Modified is doing just one leg (and she does the modified versions first).*Forward Stretches - several different forward stretches, including one that's similar to the Cobra in yoga.*Swimming - Arms out in swimming motion and legs in swimming motion.*Side lift ups, & leg raises*Legs swaying front and back*Child's pose, then Cat pose (same as a yoga Cat pose), where you are breathing in and out with your hands and knees bent on the floor, sway back in breathe, out and you roll your back out - breathing out.*She has you come up and then you're done with Matwork 1, which is where the abs pilates is on this DVD.Now for my review.I love it.  I was not able to do much of it at first.  I would literally scream when I got to the bicycles part of it.  Now I can do the whole thing!  It is a great workout, and one that beginners can really learn matwork pilates.Denise Austin is very mellow and nicely voiced on this.  Encouraging and low key.  She tells you how to breathe and is gently encouraging of you, telling the placement, hold in your abs, etc.I'm getting stronger and stronger in my abs because of this, and I think it's great.  Eventually I'll have to go to a higher level but for right now this is amazing.The first part of this DVD is 22 minutes in length.  If you can't do it all (and you won't be able to if you're not totally strong in your abs), you WILL get there!  At first I could only do a few minutes of this DVD, and now I can do it all, and I'm planning on doing it twice a day.  Plus cardio.  I feel stronger and have more stamina, and it's all because of this DVD.
summary: Great For Your Abs, Especially For Beginners & Weaklings

reviewText: Denise Austin's Mat Workout Based on the Work of J.H. Pilates features two workout segments: Mat Workout #1 (all Pilates), and Mat Workout #2 (Combination of Yoga and Pilates).Mat Workout #1 runs for 21 minutes. It features core Pilates exercises such as the Teaser, Leg Circles, the Hundred, and Leg Swings. However, Denise's almost whispered and breathy instructions leave out many details for performing the exercises correctly. The Pilates method focuses on execution, not repetition, so it is essential that the exercises be performed precisely. While Denise explains modifications for beginners, there is no one in her class that demonstrates them for you. The class, also, features people who are well toned and slim, there are no "average" people who are beginners or less flexible in the class.Denise moves very, very quickly, especially in the single leg stretch move of the first mat workout. It is too fast to keep up with at times, especially if you might be new to Pilates movements.The second workout features Yoga moves reminscent of her Yoga Essentials workout. If you are familiar with her Sun Salutations series from Yoga Essentials, you will have no problem with this workout. However, if you have not done these moves before, be sure to take your time learning this segment. It will be challenging for you.The Bonus Features of the DVD include a Buttocks and Thighs workout, Recipes, Trailer, and Pilates Poses segment. The bonus thighs section is not as well produced as the other workouts, it is not polished. For example, the camera is not steady at the beginning of the workout. The Recipes include Island Chicken with Brown Rice, and a Fruit Cobbler. The trailer features all VHS titles, few of the featured workouts are available on DVD.Overall, there are better Pilates workouts out there, especially if you are a beginner. If you are at intermediate or advanced levels, this might be something different to add to your existing routines. Bear in mind that Pilates workouts are isometric workouts. It is essential to complement this workout with cardio and strength training if you want to see results in weight loss.
summary: Pilates and Yoga Mix Workout with Bonus Features

reviewText: I bought this several years ago before ever taking a Pilates class.  Now that I'm oversees with no Pilates around I brought this back out to use. reviewText: I wanted to dislike this video.I was unfamiliar with Denise Austin when I bought it, but the minute she opened her mouth I felt an immediate, "Oh god, I've gotta listen to THAT for the next forty minutes!!" Her baby voice grates on me, I feel she's talking down to her audience, and I hate how she addresses the camera like she can see thru your TV screen ("Let me see those straight shoulders! Beautiful!")Nevermind all that, though. I gotta hand it to the lady, her first workout on this tape kicks .... Or, more appropriately, kicks ABS! It's why I gave this tape five stars, even though the second workout is [bad]. That's how good it is!Some reviewers indicate the first segment wasn't challenging enough. I suspect this is because they were not using their core so much as they were using momentum & their hip flexors to do the bulk of the work. Pilates is unique in that the more proficient you become at controlling your core, the harder you will work.I know this from experience, not just from all the pilates stuff I read. When I first started this tape, I'd had a few years of yoga under my belt and got a "three-star" workout from the first segment. Since then, I've mixed things up with running & lifting & cycling, too... I come back to this tape every few weeks, and it's amazing how much stronger my abs have become. *NEVER* have I ever done this workout without feeling it -- intensely!-- the next day. I've never been able to say that about a workout tape.Now, this progress didn't happen overnight and I'm pretty sure crosstraining has a lot to do with my strength gains, as well, but still -- this is one killer ab workout, when executed correctly. Best of all, it's also calming & gentle & even relaxing, in some ways. And, it's only 20 minutes long. Dammit, Denise, you done good.The second half of the tape, though, well, that's awful. No flow to the poses, underwhelming instruction, weird cuts to her demo'ing some postures on a rock, for some reason... blech. Stick w/ the first 20 minutes and this tape is still a value. Exercise fads may come & go but strong transverse abdominals will keep your frame supported for a lifetime!
summary: I Hate to Say It -- Props to Denise

reviewText: I use several yoga tapes in my practice, and have recently expanded into Pilates, though I have less experience in that discipline.This tape seems to be a disaster in both areas.  Oh, the routines are challenging, and because I kind of knew the basic moves, I didn't hurt anything too badly.  But Ms Austin does many things that are not only annoying, but potentially dangerous.First of all, instead of properly explaining position, breathing, and what muscles we should concentrate on, Austin constantly tells us in that irritating breathy voice of hers how beautiful and strong we are.  Second, she herself shows bad form, so if you're watching instead of listening, you're still not going to get it.  Her Warrior II (yoga) was a disaster, and on her side kicks (Pilates), she and her whole class had their torsos flopping all over the place.  In the Pilates-only workout, she concentrates too much on the abs, not giving the back nearly enough attention.  And finally, in the yoga-Pilates workout, there is no flow -- she just kind of hops and flops from one position to another -- not at all yoga-like.If you like the idea of integrating yoga and Pilates, try Jonathan Urla's Yogilates workouts.  I've tried Level One, and find it fantastic -- energizing, accessible, easy-to-follow, and just challenging enough (so far).  As I said, I have less experience with Pilates recordings, but I like the Stott Pilates tape I've tried so far (Essential Mat Work).
summary: Poorly explained, poorly executed, poor balance
Title: N/A

reviewText: Overall, I'm satisfied with this tape.  However, I'd give it a 3.5 stars if I could.  I don't think this tape is as good as the"Power Yoga Plus" tape.  This tape is much slower, and I feel that her Pilates form isn't as good as on the other tape (which makes sense, since PYP came out in 2001 and this one came out in 2000).  There is also something about the set that I don't like- it looks like the same set as what she uses for Blast Away 10 Pounds, but dressed up differently.  I think I don't like that you're supposed to think you can go right outdoors when it's clearly a set.  I also think she uses too many repetitions.  One of the things about Pilates that makes it so appealing is its emphasis on correct form; if you do the exercise correctly, you should only need to do 5-10 reps, not the plus or minus 20 she does for some of the moves here.But it's still a good tape (just not great).  She doesn't include all of the classic "beginner" Pilates moves, so the over-repetition works out.  The Yoga section on the second half of the tape is very good.  She probably isn't going to impress the hard-core yogis, but she is doing some tricky asanas (balancing on one foot and camel, for instance), and I applaud her.  Again, the thing to watch out for whenever you combine yoga and pilates is to change your breathing accordingly: yoga is all through the nose and pilates is in through the nose and out through the mouth.This isn't a bad tape to add to your collection, but if I had to choose I'd recommend Power Yoga Plus over this one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Starts with about 5 minutes of chat. Don't get me wrong, I'm glad she explained the principles. If you don't understand what the exercises are targeting and the proper way to do them, you're not going to get all you can/should out of a pilates-based workout. However, if you've had classes before - you can just skip past this part and go straight to the workout section.The workout that followed was nearly the same as the beginning level pilates classes I remember. It was good for a refresher, if you haven't done pilates in a few years, but I believe higher-intermediate or long term students may not find it exciting or challenging. I though the amount of verbal cuing was appropriate - not so much that it becomes annoying, not so little that beginners would miss out on adjustments they should make.There are two separate 20 minute workouts, which is convenient if you have limited time. The first is a pretty standard mat-based (intro level) pilates routine. The second, yoga poses mixed with a bit of what you'd get in a second level pilates class.  In that section, they keep cutting away from the gym setting to show her doing the poses in a rocky desert environment. I suppose that could help keep it a bit more visually interesting, perhaps to help put off the point where you are bored of repeating the same video, but I didn't really find it necessary.
summary: Would be great for pilates newbies

reviewText: I love Pilates but at $60 to $100 per hour for a trainer with the "machine" makes the price of the workout way out of my budget. Austin's workout is based on Pilates but all that you need is a yoga mat. The strength, balance and stretching exercises are as close as you can get to an actual Pilates workout on your own. reviewText: I am not a fan of Denise Austin, too perky, not great technique, but she changed my opinion on this!  This a great Pilates workout technique and cuing is great.  Both workouts are about 20 minutes which is great to incorparate with other workouts or use alone when time is limited.  Workout 1 is all pilates and your abs will feel strong and flat after about 3 sessions.  Workout 2 combines yoga and pilates and it is tough! This provides even more toning and opens your hips and just makes you feel lean and graceful.  For years I've had lower back problems, yoga and pilates have provided me tremendous relief.  If you're looking for a do-able pilates tape this is it.

reviewText: This was my first time trying Pilates, and I felt like it was a good video to start with.  The first time I did it I felt the burn in my lower abs for a few days after.  Since then I have not been sore, but I still feel it working when I'm doing it.  I really like the first section.  My abs are flatter now, which makes me very happy!  I have only done the second workout a few times because I don't really like it.  (Because of it I would actually rate this a 3 or 3 1/2 stars, but I mainly based my rating on the part I actually do.)  I think Denise does the yoga postures far too quickly to get the benefit of the stretch. If the moves were slower I would like it better.  Also her cuing in the section is terrible.  Overall, however, I would recommend this video to anyone who would like to get started in Pilates.  I have tried one other Pilates video--the Method Precision Toning--and really enjoyed it and felt it more, but I think it is more advanced than this video.  I'm glad I started with Denise's.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What I didn't like about this video was that Austin does not offer as thorough of an explanation of how your body is supposed to move, relying on you to figure it out from watching.  And she does not offer modified versions of the exercise, so I was afraid to try some of the more difficult pilates poses-- which other videos have given me.  I definitely think Austin is a great fitness instructor, and man, do I wish I had her abs!  But if you're a knucklehead when it comes to workouts, try the Pilates - Mat Based Workout for Beginners instead.  The instructor of that one made the exercises more obvious to me, explaining exactly what my body should be doing, and offering a way for me to get started right away, complete the whole workout, get the benefits, but not feel like a clumsy oaf.
Title: N/A

reviewText: There is nothing wrong with this DVD. The Pilates and yoga are good. Challenging at parts, which is nice, but she does V-ups a lot and while I love crunches, I'm not into full sit-ups and V-ups because I've read that they're not great for your back to be doing them over and over again. Some people might be fine with that, so whatever works for you. Parts of this were good, but because there were so many of those full sit-ups and V-ups I had to improvise and do other things that wouldn't be bad for my back. I don't have a bad back or anything, just trying to prevent that from happening. I'll probably use it again, but it won't be very often.I tried this DVD once years ago and loved it, but that was before I'd learned that stuff. If you're looking for a Pilates/Yoga workout it is a good workout for both and you feel nice and stretched afterward, which is a plus. I recommend it for that.

reviewText: If you are interested in trying Pilates, this is a mat workout for about 20 minutes.  First Denise explains basic principles to help you have a good form.  Then she introduces a gentle routine that is soothing but challenging enough.  She has several exercisers with her on the first workout. There is good explanation and cueing.On the second workout it's a combination of yoga and pilates and seems fairly challenging.  Not sure it's as apt for a beginner.  But those who want a challenge will enjoy it.  It's just Denise alone in this workout.  Denise works in the gym in this workout with desert scenes of her doing the same move on red rocks.Like the soft white poofy mats they use in the first and second routines. Denise recommends doing the first workout M-W-F and the second T-Th.  She is very encouraging.

reviewText: There are two 20-minute workout videos on this DVD.  A Pilates mat workout and a yoga workout.I like the pilates mat routine and feel like my abs receive a good workout by the end of it. reviewText: Denise Austin comes across as such an enthusiastic, positive, likable person that it is easy to misjudge her and think that she is not as knowledgeable as others who are a little more "serious" in attitude. But she graduated college with a degree in exercise physiology, has a huge fan base, and knows whereof she speaks. This DVD consists of two relatively short, effective workouts utilizing Pilates matwork and yoga (primarily the Sun Salutation sequence), both of which can give you a good, overall toning workout and enough challenge to break a sweat. Some basic familiarity with both Pilates and yoga would probably be good, but in my opinion, expert level is not required either to do the workouts or reap their benefits. This is a focused, effective pair of workouts that should be experienced over a couple of weeks to begin to see the benefits, which are considerable. Congratulations, Denise!
summary: Denise Austin in Another Great DVD Workout!
